doc.field: Kinkel and Ruehe disagree on NATO intervention in Kosovo

The federal government continues to be at odds over the possibility of military intervention by NATO in Kosovo. Foreign Minister Kinkel stressed that a UN mandate would be necessary for involvement. According to Defense Minister Ruehe, however, NATO could intervene without an existing vote by the Security Council. Chancellor Kohl has not yet commented on the conflict. SPD and Buendnis-Gruene also consider a UN mandate to be necessary for NATO military action.
Russian military representative at NATO leaves Berlin

The Russian military representative at NATO returned to Moscow for personal reasons. The chairman of the NATO Military Committee, Naumann, stated that General Savarsin (sp?) had not been ordered to return because of protest against NATO air maneuvers, as was first reported. The Russian general renewed his visa. It had been reported that Russia had been annoyed with NATO air maneuvers over Macedonia and Albania.
All first-generation ICE trains to be converted

Barely 2 weeks after the train accident in Eschede with more than 100 deaths, the Federal Railways began the conversion of all firstgeneration ICE trains. Operation of 59 ICE trains with old tires was prohibited by the Federal Railways Office in Bonn. A press release stated that the prohibition will remain in effect until evidence of an operational safety has been firmly established. The railway accident in Eschede is said to have been caused by a faulty tire. Two of the 59 old ICE trains were back in service today with new wheels. According to the Federal Railways, the remaining 57 trains will be equipped with brand new wheels or solid wheels like those found on second-generation ICE trains. 120 replacement trains are currently in use. Delays of up to 30 minutes can still be expected in the next few days. It is not possible to predict how long the conversion will take. Federal President Herzog will take part in Sunday=92s funeral ceremonies for the victims of Eschede.
Two people die in a collosion between train and passenger car

A local train collided with a passenger train in Bad Muenster-Eifel. Two people died, and two more received life-threatening injuries. According to the Federal Railways, the train had collided with the car at a railroad crossing without gates and dragged the car for approximately 20 meters.
Deutsche Bank denies assisting customers in tax evasions

The Deutsche Bank denied having given customers systematic assistance in tax evasions. Based on suspicion, a large force of approximately 300 investigators searched the bank=92s central office in Frankfurt and branch offices in several other cities. Employees of Deutsche Bank are said to have assisted customers in avoiding the Treasury and investing their money in Luxemburg and Switzerland.
Baden-Wuerttemberg prohibits transports of nuclear waste

Baden-Wuerttemberg will not allow any new transports of nuclear waste from its 3 nuclear power plants until violations of exceeding radioactive limits from mid-May are completely resolved. Environmental Minister Schaufler said, following a meeting with the managers of the nuclear power plants, that any future limit violations must be avoided during the whole transport. His ministry had created a working team in order to ensure that this demand be met.
Front National and DVU want to join forces

Together with the right-wing Deutsche Volksunion, the French right-wing radical party National Front wants to fight against the inflow of foreigners and the introduction of the Euro. According to the chairpersons after a meeting in Strassbourg, the two right-extremist parties will form a parliamentary group, if they are elected to the European Parliament in the next year.
German soccer fans fight with French police

An hour before the start of the World Cup game between Germany and the United States, German fans fought with French police, throwing bottles and rocks at the officers. Approximately 300 Germans attempted to break through the barricades in front of the stadium.
